clinical_study.brief_title: The Effect Methylphenidate Hydrochloride on Pain and Auditory Sensitivity in Healthy Subjects
clinical_study.official_title: The Effect of Ritalin (Methylphenidate Hydrochloride) on Pain and Auditory Sensitivity: an Exploratory Double-blind Randomized Controlled Trial on Healthy Subjects

brief_summary.textblock:
1. To examine whether Ritalin has analgesic properties in healthy subjects.
2. To examine if Ritalin analgesic effect is a pain specific phenomenon or a part of a broader, non-specific effect on high mental functions.

primary_outcome.measure: Experimental pain intensity measured on a visual analogue scale (0-100)

secondary_outcome.measure: effect of Ritalin on auditory sensitivity, measured by the response to different auditory stimulations
pain intensity (NPS 0-100) in response to thermal stimuli and the measures of the auditory tests.

arm_group.description: The study will include two sessions which will be conducted at the same time of the day, one week apart from each other. Each session will last approximately 6 hours. In each session subjects will be exposed to baseline experimental pain models and auditory tests. Then they will receive either one MP SR 20 mg tablet or an identical looking placebo.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Male subjects between the ages of 20 to 40
- Healthy subjects without known disease and without any chronic pain
- Subjects without known cognitive problems, which can understand the research and its goals
- Subjects who are not taking any medications
- Subjects without hearing problems
- Subjects without attention deficit disorder (ADHD) problems
Exclusion Criteria:
- Subjects who are known to suffer from any disease or any chronic pain
- Subjects taking psychotropic drugs (except Ritalin) or any analgesics
- Subjects who have any contradictions for ritalin administration
- subjects with suspected cognitive disability
